newsitem.title: USA: UN says 1st Iraqi oil contract okayed, new ones in.
newsitem.headline: UN says 1st Iraqi oil contract okayed, new ones in.

text.p: The United Nations approved the first Iraqi oil contract on Tuesday and received two new ones for approval, a U.N. spokesman said.

He wouldn't give details but the first approved contract is widely believed to be for the Turkish state oil company Tupras, which earlier Tuesday said in a statement that it would take 75,000 barrels per day from the Iraqi State Oil Marketing Organisation (SOMO) immediately and had submitted a contract for approval.

No price was disclosed but it wasn't submitted for special approval to the U.N. Sanctions Committee on Iraq and therefore must have followed the formulas agreed to, which for European customers for December delivery was $1.55 a barrel below benchmark North Sea Brent blend, diplomats said. They said the contract would run for six months.
Diplomats said Elf Aquitaine had submitted a contract which was rejected on technical grounds, basically because it was submitted through the wrong channels.

The contracts have begun to come in for approval following the final approval by U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros Ghali on Monday of the "oil-for-food" deal, allowing Iraq to sell up to $2 billion of oil over six months (renewable) to pay for badly needed food, medicines and other humanitarian supplies.
The contracts must be approved by four overseers contracted by the U.N. Secretariat and the procedures set out under the terms of the U.N.-Iraq agreement must be strictly adhered to.
